newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada province cancels U.S. military lease over fish.
newsitem.headline: Canada province cancels U.S. military lease over fish.

text.p: British Columbia said on Friday it will cancel the lease on an underwater military testing range used by the United States to pressure Ottawa and Washington to resolve a dispute over Pacific salmon fishing.
Provincial Premier Glen Clark told reporters that British Columbia decided to revoke the lease on the seabed at the Nanoose Bay submarine and weapons testing ground off Vancouver Island.
The Canadian Forces Maritime Experimental Test Range at Nanoose Bay is also used by U.S. nuclear submarines under a Canada-U.S. joint defense agreement.
The province controls the sea floor and Clark said the move would effectively end the U.S. military's use of the area as a torpedo test range.
"We have got to take some kind of dramatic action to get their attention," Clark said.
He said British Columbia felt compelled to act unilaterally because time was running out before the salmon run starts in July.

Canada said on Wednesday that talks with the United States over the the long-running dispute had collapsed. Negotiators had sought to reach an accord on how to share dwindling salmon stocks in the Pacific Northwest.
